1003718186129190914.text:
7/The question of scale — and/or spread & replication — of good innovations is the great question of US public education. As Bill Clinton is purported to have noted early on in his presidency. 

https://ssir.org/articles/entry/going_to_scale …pic.twitter.com/KpUa7h9Co3

1003718181939269634.text:
6/ R&D is defining and researching critical questions, like:
-how should the role of the teacher evolve?

And developing new solutions that attempt to answer the question.
-like the innovative staffing model of @Distinctive_Edu; @CICSWestBelden was recently profiled herepic.twitter.com/l9mJUUro8X

1003718180408307713.text:
5/ The work of education innovation -- perhaps like all innovation -- has two parts. 

R&D and scale.

All of it oriented around cycles of inquiry on the topic of the future of schools & learning.

1003718171466125314.text: 4/ Thinking about how little the teaching profession has changed over the past 100 years -- compared to how much other professions that existed back then, like: farmers and doctors -- illuminates the need education innovation.pic.twitter.com/ZsYo0iOs3a

1003718170623004677.text: 3/ Young people admirably choosing to teach in our public schools should similarly expect to have their jobs evolve over the coming decades. The teaching profession — and the schools and districts where it operates — have not evolved at the same rate as the rest of society.

1003718168370696192.text:
2/ We don't know what tomorrow's jobs look like, but we know that they will likely require us: (i) to differentiate our value prop in relation to intelligent machines, and (ii) to be continuously curious & upskilling. 

See the @jseelybrown talk our Post AlphaGo world for more.pic.twitter.com/FUyjtOCYQw

1003718167456354304.text:
Some notes on education innovation. 

1/ Knowing how to navigate and access the evolving world of work is essential for young people entering the professional world today. They won't be performing the same tasks for an entire career.
